description: Children should be fed small amounts of food that increases in variety and quantity as they grow.
title: Children should be fed small amounts of food that increases in variety and quantity as they grow
content:
**6–8 months:**

 - Infants should breastfeed frequently and receive other foods 2-3
   times a day.

 - Infants can eat pureed or mashed foods, thick soups and porridges.

 - Meat, eggs and fish can be given. These must be mashed, minced or cut
   into very small pieces.

 - Start with 2–3 spoonfuls per feeding, increasing gradually to 1/2 of
   a 250-millilitre cup.


----------


**9–24 months:**

 - Children should receive other foods 3-4 times a day in addition to
   breastfeeding.

 - Give infants aged 9–11 months 1/2 of a 250-millilitre cup per
   feeding.

 - Provide children aged 12–23 months 3/4 to 1 whole 250-millilitre cup
   per feeding.

 - Give children 2 years and older at least 1 whole 250-millilitre cup
   per feeding.  Meat, fish and eggs, should be included as much as
   possible.


----------

**By 12 months:**

 - Most children can eat 'family foods' of a solid consistency.
   Semi-solid foods can still be given as it is easier for young
   children to eat.

 - Nutritious snacks such as fruit, bread or bread with nut paste can be
   given 1-2 times a day, as desired, starting at 6 months.

 - If the quality or amount of food per meal is low, or the child is no
   longer breastfeeding, give 1–2 cups of milk and 1-2 extra meals each
   day.
